awd_titl_txt: Resolving the Fates of Multiple Triplet Excitons in Single Multi-Chromophoric Conjugated Organic molecules
awd_abstract_narration:
Organic polymers are long chains of repeating molecular subunits. When they absorb light, some segments of the chain are placed in excited energy states that live for about a billionth of a second. However, a fraction of this energy can become trapped in lower energy states that last much longer, perhaps a thousand times longer. These longer-lived states can interact with each other, as well as excess charges existing on the chain, which poses significant challenges for using polymers in emerging technologies, such as light-emitting diodes and solar energy conversion devices. With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor John Grey at University of New Mexico is studying these long-lived states over a broad range of time scales. Working with his students, Professor Grey is using microscopy methods that can observe single polymer chains to determine how the chain structure and packing influence these long-lived excitations. Their discoveries could inform the design of new polymers. In addition, Professor Grey, who is a veteran himself, is engaging with student veteran groups at the University of New Mexico to increase participation of veteran and non-traditional students in STEM fields though weekly 'lunch and learn' and tutoring sessions. The long-term goal is to improve enrollment and retention of student veterans by recognizing their unique experience and engaging them as leaders in classroom and laboratory settings.

The project examines the population dynamics of spin-forbidden (triplet) excited states in multi-chromophoric conjugated polymers and molecular light harvesting arrays. Hybrid single molecule spectroscopy techniques and stochastic kinetic modeling are the primary physical probes used to resolve interactions between multiple triplets spanning time scales from approximately 1 ns up to steady-state conditions. The goal is to be able to count the number of triplets on a single molecule at any given time, and to resolve how these states and their interactions with other excited states evolve with increasing structural (morphological) complexity. This project also exposes new kinetic insights of bimolecular annihilation processes that are often difficult to measure reliably at the bulk material level. The research further utilizes collaborations with synthetic materials chemists to investigate how fine tuning of molecular structure impacts population dynamics of multiple interacting excited states. Student participants gain valuable skills in physical and materials chemistry as well as theoretical modeling vital for the advancement of National science and technology interests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project has been published in six peer-reviewed articles including one manuscript that has been submitted recently to the Journal of Physical Chemistry. The project has provided research-training opportunities for six graduate and three undergraduate students. The goal of the scientific research is to understand excited processes in conjugated organic chromophores that provides fundamental insights to advance organic materials for solar cells, light emitting diodes and emergent functional materials. In particular, understanding the splitting of one quanta of excitation energy of a singlet spin multiplicity to two quanta of energy of triplet spin multiplicity after absorption of photon energy has been the focus of the project. This process, which is known as singlet fission has important implication for enabling multiexciton generation and enhancing light energy harvesting efficiency of organic materials. Fluorescence-based spectroscopic probes have been used to detect and investigate intramolecular singlet-fission (iSF) activity in organic semiconductors with large substituents such as tetracene/pentacene (acenes) derivatives. Photophysical models are simulated from several iSF-active systems reported in the literature using a stochastic approach to assess the sensitivity of steady-state fluorescence to the presence of triplet excitons. The results demonstrate large fluctuations in expected fluorescence yields with varying excitation rate constants for systems with iSF yield exceeding 50%. The approach entails the use of repetitive rectangular-shaped excitation waveforms as a stimulus, with durations comparable to triplet lifetimes. We observe unique dynamics signatures that can be directly related to relaxation of multi-exciton states involved over the entire effective time of singlet fission in the presence and absence of an excitation light stimulus. In particular, time-dependent fluorescence yields display an abrupt decay followed by slower rise dynamics appearing as a prominent ?dip? feature in responses. The initial fast decrease in the fluorescence yield arises from the formation of triplet pairs and separated triplets that do not produce emission resembling a complete ground state bleach effect. However, relaxation of one separated triplet allows the system to absorb, and in some cases, this increases the fluorescence yield, causing rise dynamics in the emissive response. Our approach also permits extrapolation of all multi-exciton state population dynamics up to steady state conditions in addition to the ability to explore consequences of alternative relaxation channels. The results demonstrate that it is possible to resolve unique signatures of singlet fission events from dynamic fluorescence studies, which can augment detection capabilities and extend sensitivity limits and accessible time scales.

Nanofibers of poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT) have been investigated using single molecule spectroscopy. We have shown that the P3HT nanofibers assembled in anisole solutions contain both crystalline and amorphous structures with distinct electronic properties. The different behaviors of structures toward photoinduced interaction with oxygen is then revealed using photoluminescence (PL) imaging at different excitation intensity. Nanofiber regions with low PL yields tend to show faster PL intensity saturation that also degrade much faster following periods of high excitation intensity. Conversely, other regions show gains in PL intensity and virtually no saturation. These PL ?gainer? and ?loser? behaviors are assigned as originating from amorphous and crystalline P3HT packing structures.

Fluorescence quenching dynamics on time scales comparable to triplet lifetimes (μs to ms) are used to reveal population dynamics in multichromophoric polymers that likely support coexisting multiple triplets. Stochastic photodynamic models are then used to extract key kinetic constants, including bimolecular triplet?triplet annihilation, that tend to exhibit pronounced dependences on polymer conformational ordering. Our study shows that molecular-level control can be harnessed to more accurately manage triplet yields and interactions over a large range of time scales.

The physicochemical behaviors of molecular photon emitters have been studied by comparing the surface enhanced Raman scattering spectra of model organic chromophores [methylene blue (MB), azure A (AzA) and toluidine blue o (TBO)] in vacuum and in air. It is shown that the chromophores are relatively stable in vacuum, while they undergo N-demethylation reaction when excited at ambient condition. Comparison of the vacuum and ambient data suggests that the photochemical transformation is preceded by fluorescence quenching that involves intersystem crossing, energy transfer and singlet oxygen generation. The light induced physicochemical behaviors of the three model system are similar with some notable exceptions. Strongest signal fluctuation is observed for the N-demethylation product of MB due to most significant disruption of the adsorption geometry as four methyl groups are eliminated, leaving the product in metastable state. On the other hand, TBO appears to be most effective photosensitizer as evidenced by the most significant extent of N-demethylation within 0.5 s of exposure as well as through comparison of the N-demethylation signature in vacuum due to trace amount of oxygen. The results of this study have important implications in the study of molecular polaritons in optical nanocavities as well as in understanding the photostability of organic materials.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2022
Modified by: Terefe G Habteyes
